seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences.
text: The issue of police brutality, and even general misconduct, is certainly an important issue. I agree that the public needs to be aware of possible abuses of authority, particularly as they relate to criminal charges, and scrutinize each individual case. This is especially true in the case of law enforcement. However, past and recent events have shown that the media sensationalizes police misconduct (real, exaggerated, or imagined) when ever the purported victim of said misconduct is a member of a 'protected class'. This creates the impression that certain communities are unfairly targeted and treated harshly for no good reason, up to the point of being denied not only their constitutional rights but also their humanity. Not only does this turn the focus away from the facts on the ground, but it perpetuates a myth that has been used to cover up the results of failed social experiments.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences.
text:
I understand your sentiment and do concur with you on certain aspects; with that stated, there are certain things that I would like to address and counter.

You asserted that the alleged perpetrator's "rights" would be violated. But keep in mind, the ability to be on a college campus (or not to be excluded) is not something that is protected by statute or regulation. I do agree that the alleged perpetrator should have his/her day in court, whether it be through formal legal proceedings or via the college administration.

Furthermore, your response strictly concerns the "right" of the alleged perpetrator. But think of this issue from the perspective of the victim. Often times, the ensuing moments, days, weeks that follow are the most challenging times as the victim tries to reconcile this traumatic experience. The possibility of encountering the perpetrator on campus is unsettling, at the very least, to the victim.
seedtext: To immediately remove someone who has been accused of a crime is against their rights. You cannot place judgement until proof is given, an accusation alone is not enough and is unfair to all involved. seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

The chip on your shoulder is very easy to see. You insist that the police do their job flawlessly but please make sure the perpetrators are not people of color.
seedtext: I completely disagree with this statement. First, reporting about the loss of a life is never overblown. Second we know, and have seen through body cameras and cell phone video, that there is a problem with the way law enforcement interacts with people of color. In fact, people of color are more likely to experience excessive use of force than their white counterparts. This is even true in similar instances. This is not to say that all law enforcement is bad. In fact most law enforcement is here to serve and protect. However, it does point to cultural issues within the institution that must be addressed to restore trust between the groups.

commit: "I will answer each question with at least three full sentences"
text: Over reacting to police confrontations, can be deadly to the public in general. When animosity towards the police rises, as it has in Chicago, police do not feel safe, going into the ghetto neighborhoods. Therefore those people, in those neighborhood, literally, have to fend for themselves, because if they need the police and call for their help, the police can't help those in need there, because they will likely be shot at themselves.
seedtext: The public reaction has not been overblown, if anything it is severely muted.  Recent confrontations are simply making visible issues that have existed for a very long time. Lynchings and killings of minorities have happened throughout American history. However, now we have proof in real time through cell phone videos and Facebook Live. There are real issues between police and the communities they serve that are only being addressed because of the attention being paid through Black Lives Matter and other protests. This is how things improve, even if it is hard and difficult to discuss.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences.
text:
I agree that immediate action must be taken. School support of victims is also extremely important. A victim needs immediate attention. Special support services need to be in place to help the victim through this crisis in the most positive way possible. A victim should never be made to feel that it is their fault, and be made safe through environmental, classroom, social situations. They should never be left alone immediately following a sexual assault, a friend or trusted relative, etc., should accompany them through this process. 
I do not entirely disagree with removal of an alleged perpetrator. I think it needs some refinement in order to protect their rights as well. Such as having an in house suspension of sorts. Where the accused is kept separate from the rest of campus, always supervised, and is also able to continue with studies. If said accused is charged with the assault, then have them removed permanently.
seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences
text: I slightly agree. I think the media has made a huge impact on the recent reactions of people to these incidents. I think that it's made to seem like the police are the bad guys trying to go around and wrongfully accuse minorities of things that just aren't happening.
seedtext: Yes it has been overblown.  The media has portrayed these incidents to be much more common than they actually are, which has fueled the public reaction to be greater than necessary.  The public reaction has largely overlooked the fact that the majority of these incidents have been started with a suspect resisting a lawful arrest.  It has focused almost exclusively on the officer's actions and ignored the fact that nothing detrimental would have occurred had the suspect complied with the officer's orders.  There has also been rioting and destruction by some in the public that has not accomplished anything positive.  Another overreaction is in the public's call for an immediate termination or filing of criminal charges against an officer when there has not been adequate time to conduct a thorough investigation of the officer's actions.

This type of precedent sets up mainly male students but could also set up female students as well to be in a position where they are in constant fear. Now if there is immediate proof then I completely agree that they should be kicked out, however without a good amount of evidence to prove something happened then I think kicking the students off campus should wait.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences
text: I disagree with immediate removal of an accused perpetrator.  When an accusation is made, the accuser and accused should be kept apart. Neither should be enrolled in the same class, and a university can make sure that neither crosses the other's path through re scheduling.  In cases where a false accusation is made, removing the accused will have a severe impact emotionally for the accused, who may actually be the victim.  An investigation into the allegations should take place right away to determine if removal from the campus is warranted. Removal should not precede an investigation, as it could aid the real culprit in the case of false accusations..

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences.
text: Under normal circumstances, meaning outside of the context of college, when a person is accused of assault, the police come and arrest them. If they can't make bail then they are held until trial. This apparently does not violate the "basic right, enshrined in our constitution" that you reference.  Therefore, the proposed policy of removing someone from campus immediately does not either.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences
text: Sexual assault is an extremely serious matter and should be dealt with swiftly and harshly. However there is a major difference between someone who is accused of sexual assault and someone who has committed sexual assault. Everyone has a right to due process and it would be irresponsible to remove someone based solely on an accusation. I believe that facts should be gathered quickly, witnesses spoken to immediately and testimony taken as quickly as possible so a determination can be made of what realistically happened and action taken from there. But it is completely wrong to remove someone from campus based only on an accusation.
seedtext: Not only should the person who has been accused of sexual assault be immediately removed from campus, but should be removed from society. The horrors that victims face just knowing that the predator may still be out there can cause all sorts of stress and post traumatic stress. The sooner that we can get someone who is convicted and proven to be dangerous off of the street, the better for all of us in society.

seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences
text: Sexual assault allegations on college campuses are a problem and should be taken extremely seriously by universities and law enforcement. However, one of the cornerstones of our justice system is 'innocent until proven guilty'. It is unfair to the accused to be removed from their college campus, let alone society, before the facts can be gathered. While the stress and PTSD are unfortunate after effects of assault, I believe it is equally criminal to ruin a persons life before all the facts are in. I propose a no contact order between the victim and the accused until a thorough investigation can be conducted. Additionally, to protect both parties, no names should be released and the file should be sealed until it can be tried in the courts.
seedtext: Not only should the person who has been accused of sexual assault be immediately removed from campus, but should be removed from society. The sooner that we can get someone who is convicted and proven to be dangerous off of the street, the better for all of us in society.

It is immoral to treat all accused criminals as if they are guilty, as with any crime false identification is a very real possibility, not to mention personally motivated false accusations. A rush to punishment without allowing for due process is wrong, even if it seems frustrating to the victims.  I think instead steps should be taken to separate the alleged victim from the accused, and that may or may not include removal from campus until the conclusion of the investigation, but I don't think anyone should be thrown out of school over an accusation.
seedtext: Not only should the person who has been accused of sexual assault be immediately removed from campus, but should be removed from society. No one can justify allowing someone to continue to terrorize others. Unfortunately, we have to wait for the wheels of justice to turn to put away predators. The horrors that victims face just knowing that the predator may still be out there can cause all sorts of stress and post traumatic stress. The sooner that we can get someone who is convicted and proven to be dangerous off of the street, the better for all of us in society.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences.
text: I believe that most people have nor experienced mistreatment by the police and courts. I also believe that unequal treatment by authorities is different between different ethnic groups. Since this inequality and mistreatment of its citizens has become common behavior by the police and courts then the citizens of our community have a right to publicly protest the treatment they are receiving.
seedtext: I disagree with this statement for a few reasons. The public reaction has had the benefit of forcing the issues of police misconduct which generations of Americans have experienced with no justice or protection to the forefront of public policy in the country.  Without public pressure and a serious acknowedgement of unqeual protection under the law , these crimes against minority communities would continue to be swept under the rug. Also, if the situations were not broadcast in everyone's living rooms, the general majority public who many times have no experience with these injustices, nor knowlege of how  injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere will feel like they dont have a vested interest in developing solutions to the core issues that cause crime (i.e. lack of economic development, race, community distrust etc). If the instances of police brutality and incarceration were being perpetuated on the majority class there would be no end to the public confrontation.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences
text: I understand the points that you've brought up, and even agree with your statements that allow for the accused to be considered innocent until proven otherwise. I also acknowledge that your argument makes provisions for victims safety, and notes clear exceptions for when it may make sense to remove a violent offender that is a potential risk to others on campus. I would suggest that you may wish to go a bit further in providing for the victim's level of comfort by providing access to sexual assault or intimate partner violence counseling from trained professionals to assist in the process of disclosing and unpacking the repercussions of the reported abuse.
seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process. If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process. The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

commit: I will answer each question with at least three full sentences.
text:
I agree that the proportion of adversarial police contacts to the number of total police contacts on any given day in the US is skewed by the media.  To be sure, almost all police contacts are virtually non-violent or carry no overt displays of police aggression, brutality against minorities, or corruption by officers.  There is a lot to be said about media hype and over-reporting on the cases that achieve notoriety. 

That said, I don't think we can be totally dismissive in a "few bad apples" argument.  The nature of policing in this country has moved from settling neighborhood disputes and pursuing traffic violations, in many regions, into scenes of modern warfare, with emphasis on heavily armed, trigger-happy, officer-involved shootings.  It isn't necessarily fair, but police officers are held to a higher standard of conduct, and a significant trend of violent contact against minorities and unarmed citizens is more than a fluke or irregularity.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process. If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.

But we cant punish the accused automatically. By assuming someone is guilty until proven innocent, we are potentially causing issues further down the line. Setting a precedent like this can allow for malicious abuse of our justice system until there is potentially nothing left. The accused has a right to a fair trial and is guaranteed this by the Constitution. 

On the other hand, the legal process isnt perfect and is lengthy. In this situation, the accused should be responsible for switching schools or leaving all together. Additionally, the accused should wear an ankle bracelet to prevent stalking. This will allow the victim to feel secure at school and the courts to decide whether the accused is guilty.
seedtext: Not only should the person who has been accused of sexual assault be immediately removed from campus, but should be removed from society. No one can justify allowing someone to continue to terrorize others. Unfortunately, we have to wait for the wheels of justice to turn to put away predators. The horrors that victims face just knowing that the predator may still be out there can cause all sorts of stress and post traumatic stress. The sooner that we can get someone who is convicted and proven to be dangerous off of the street, the better for all of us in society.

seedtext: Of course a sexual assault allegation is a serious matter and should be treated as such. A victim should have the right to be believed in their accusation, however one of the major tenets of our judicial system and our society even is the right of the accused to be considered innocent until proven guilty. It is this basic right, enshrined in our constitution that protects citizens from unjust, vengeful or malicious persecution. I would be fine with a victim having extra physical or restraining order protection if deemed necessary, but the rights of the accused are just as important as those of the accuser. There may be limited circumstances where an accused person may need to be barred from campus or otherwise restrained, such as previous violent convictions or documented behavior.

seedtext: The alleged perpetrator should be immediately removed from campus, though not necessarily immediately expelled without due process.  The removal is for the mental and physical safety of the victim, which is the most important thing.  It shows that the school supports the victim and that sexual violence will not be tolerated.  At that point, the school and police authorities can begin their investigation, but the victim can feel safer that he or she won't run into that person in class or in other school buildings.  The vast, vast majority of alleged victims are telling the truth.  There are always exceptions, but these are few and far between.  We must believe victims and must assume that they are telling the truth, so immediate removal of the accused is certainly necessary, for the safety of the accuser as well as other women on campus.  If an investigation concludes that the assault did not happen, the appropriate corrections can be made at that time.  But it is important to err on the side of caution and protecting victims.
